clusters.title: Teenagers stabbed to death on way home from basketball
clusters.neutral_headline: Two Melbourne Teenagers Fatally Stabbed After Basketball Game

items.title: Teenagers stabbed to death on way home from basketball
items.standfirst: Two Melbourne teenagers stabbed to death in Cobblebank were on their way home from basketball.
items.content: Two Melbourne teenagers stabbed to death in Cobblebank were on their way home from basketball.

items.title: Police probe potential mistaken identity after two kids stabbed to death
items.standfirst: Two boys killed in a suspected machete attack in Melbourne's west were on their way home from basketball when they were ambushed in a potential case of mistake identity.
items.content: Two boys killed in a suspected machete attack in Melbourne's west were on their way home from basketball when they were ambushed in a potential case of mistaken identity.Dau Akueng, 15, and Chol Achiek, 12, were walking from a bus stop in Cobblebank with a third friend just before 8pm yesterday when they were set upon by up to eight masked people. The pair were found critically injured on the street about 200 metres apart in what police have described as having "the hallmarks of a youth gang crime". Neighbours reported hearing their screams and rushed outside to help but it was too late." It's absolutely shocking that not one, but two could happen so close to home, at 8 o'clock at night," one neighbour told 9News.Police said the victims weren't gang members and were investigating if their deaths were a horrific case of mistaken identity.The boy's grieving family and friends are pleading for justice.Dau's father said he needed answers for his son."This is a basketball player, he's not a criminal," Elbino Akueng said."I'm talking on behalf of my community, this is happening to us.READ MORE: Man dies after early morning shooting in Melbourne's CBD"In the last month, we have buried four kids, similar incidents keep happening, but there's no answer from police." Emergency services first found Chol, who paramedics tried to resuscitate but couldn't save.Chol's father, Cauti Nuong, described him as a "good boy" who was very clever."Very intelligent, he's always so active," he told 9News. Detective Inspector Graham Banks said Dau, 15, was found dead a short time later nearby on Cobble Street as a result of "significant injuries consistent with being stabbed".He added that Chol and Dau were not gang members. READ MORE: Beaches closed after surfer killed in shark attack"Both murders are linked to the same offenders," Banks said."Witness and CCTV vision shows the murders were committed by a large group of male offenders who appear to be covered with face masks."They fled the scene in a vehicle that is yet to be identified and vision shows that they were armed with machetes."While the investigation is in its early stages, police believe the attacks have "the hallmarks of a youth gang crime"."It is one of the most horrific crimes in a substantial and growing list of crimes of this nature," Banks said."Police are appealing for witnesses to come forward and that includes people who will know these offenders."Given the time of night, it will be anticipated that a number of vehicles were around that vicinity and enough of those cars will have dashcam footage.READ MORE:Teenage boy dies after 'stolen car' crashes during police pursuit "We appeal for people who will have knowledge of this crime and that will include people known to the offenders to come forward."You can do it anonymously but you can also report it formally."Banks said police would work to determine a motive for the stabbings."When we see crimes of this nature sometimes occur, there has been occasion where people have been targeted by mistaken identity," Banks said."There is potential that the offenders know these people and they've been specifically targeted as well, but there's also clearly a possibility that it's been a case of mistaken identity and that this is what has occurred." READ MORE: China criticises Australian and Canadian warships transiting Taiwan Strait The masked men are believed to be older than the victims. Dau has been remembered as a bright and talented young basketballer. Collingwood Basketball Association (CBA) general manager Trent Pearson said he was a "much-loved member" of the club."He was a highly talented player and referee with a cheerful personality who touched all those he interacted with over many years," Pearson said."Dau had a smile and confidence that were infectious and his love for basketball and being around his friends will be sorely missed.""As a club we are devastated by his passing. I've spoken today to the family and our focus now, is supporting them and our club members in coming to terms with the tragic loss of a beautiful young man."CBA vice president Duré De Winter said Dau "brightened everyone's day with his smile" and spoke of his maturity on and off the court." We are heartbroken to lose such a beautiful young man. Our thoughts and condolences go to his family and community, they are a strong and beautiful community," Winter said."We are so sorry for their loss."Police and the NSW State Emergency Service spent the night in the street gathering evidence. "The exact circumstances surrounding the deaths are still being determined but are believed to be connected," Victoria Police said in a statement earlier today."At this time police are treating it as a targeted attack and the investigation remains ongoing."Anyone with information is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

ai_summary: Two teenagers were fatally stabbed in Cobblebank, Melbourne, after a basketball game.
Police are investigating the possibility of mistaken identity in the attack.
The victims were on their way home when they were ambushed.
The attack is being investigated as a potential machete attack.
The incident occurred in Melbourne's west, prompting a police investigation.

items.standfirst: Detectives have charged a 26-year-old man following a pursuit in Pakenham early today.
items.content: A man has been charged with murder after a man's body was discovered in Melbourne's north-east earlier this week.Police are investigating a suspicious death after a 27-year-old man was found dead on a driveway on Linden Avenue in Ivanhoe on Tuesday.The cause of his death is yet to be determined.READ MORE: Man dies after early morning shooting in Melbourne's CBDDetectives have since charged a 26-year-old man following a pursuit in Pakenham early today.He was charged with one count of murder.The charged man will appear before Melbourne Magistrates' Court today.A second man, aged 25, was also arrested following the pursuit.READ MORE: Beaches closed, shark net removal trial paused after surfer killedPolice allege the two men had been driving a stolen car on Power Road in Doveton just before 2am today.The car allegedly evaded officers and drove through Officer before being dumped on Darwin Way in Pakenham, where the offenders fled on foot, police said.The pair were arrested shortly after on Botanic Drive.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. clusters.title: Trial to remove shark nets from three NSW beaches on hold after fatal attack
clusters.neutral_headline: Shark Attack Pauses NSW Beach Net Removal Trial

items.title: Trial to remove shark nets from three NSW beaches on hold after fatal attack
items.standfirst: The NSW premier says the decision to put the brakes on the trial is "the right thing to do" after a shark claimed the life of surfer Mercury Psillakis.
items.content: The NSW premier says the decision to put the brakes on the trial is "the right thing to do" after a shark claimed the life of surfer Mercury Psillakis.

items.title: Beaches closed, net removal trial paused after surfer, 57, killed in shark attack
items.standfirst: Experienced surfer Mercury Psillakis, 57, suffered catastrophic injuries and died at the scene after being mauled by a "large" shark about 10am while surfing at Dee Wh
items.content: T he state government has paused a planned trial to take down shark nets from Sydney beaches after a man was killed in fatal shark attack yesterday.Experienced surfer Mercury Psillakis, 57, suffered catastrophic injuries and died at the scene after being mauled by a "large" shark about 10am while surfing at Long Reef Beach near Dee Why.A NSW shark net trial to remove three nets this summer has now been halted, NSW Premier Chris Minns has confirmed.READ MORE: Two boys aged 12 and 15 stabbed to death in Melbourne's west "We need to understand what happened and how it happened," Minns told Sky News, after describing the attack as an "awful tragedy"."I think it's also worth reporting that Dee Why is a netted beach and was not going to be part of the trial, so I need to understand whether the shark got inside the nets or how the system's operating, before we make big moves."Documents obtained via freedom of information laws found over 200 sea creatures, including dolphines, turtles and endangered grey nurse sharks, were killed by the nets last summer. The trial would have seen three beaches across Waverley, Northern Beaches and Central Coast councils have nets removed.READ MORE: Putin says foreign troops deployed to Ukraine would be legitimate targetsREAD MORE: Wealthy US family 'matriarch' convicted of ex-son-in-law's murderNets were installed on Monday at 51 beaches between Newcastle and Wollongong.The NSW government annually installs mesh nets at beaches up and down the coast every summer, along with drumlines, drone surveillance and listening stations as part of a $21.5 million shark safety initiativeNorthern Beaches Police Area Commander John Duncan yesterday said the attack was a "freak incident that happens very, very rarely".There has not been a fatal shark attack on a netted NSW beach since 1951. The exact species of shark which attacked Psillakis remains unknown, however a great white was detected by drumlines prior to the incident.Beaches across Sydney's northern region remained closed today as members of the Dee Why Surf Life Saving Club patrolled the water and monitored it via drones.President of the Surf Life Saving - Sydney Northern Beaches Rob McGibbon said Dee Why wold remain closed for up to 72 hours.The attack took place south of the lagoon at Long Reef, a section of the popular beach which is netted. Local surfer Angela Edwards, told The Sydney Morning Herald that she wanted to see more tag-and-release and drones to keep the beach safe."We have to co-exist, and we have the technology," she said.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

ai_summary: A shark attack resulted in the death of surfer Mercury Psillakis, age 57.
The attack occurred at Dee Why beach in Sydney.
The NSW government paused the shark net removal trial.
The surfer suffered catastrophic injuries and died at the scene.
Beaches have been closed following the fatal shark attack.

items.title: WA museum tells staff ‘almost all of us are guilty’ of burning fossil fuels in email defending Woodside partnership
items.standfirst: Exclusive: Climate advocates reject CEO’s claim he is ‘not qualified’ to comment on risks of gas firm’s plan to extend production to 2070Follow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastThe head of the Western Australian Museum has told staff that burning fossil fuels is something “almost all of us are guilty of in one way or another” in an email defending the institution’s renewed research partnership with Woodside.The museum’s chief executive, Alec Coles, sent the email to staff before a Woodside-sponsored August open day at the Maritime Museum – one of WA Museum’s seven locations. It came amid public criticism of the extension of the “longstanding collaboration”, in which the gas company supports the museum’s biodiversity research along the WA coastline. Continue reading...
